titleStmt.title: Vachel Lindsay - The Congo: A Study of the Negro Race (1914). Analysis
titleStmt.author: Jeannette Eileen Jones

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

div1.head: Analysis
div1.p: In the introduction to Nicholas Vachel Lindsay's 1914 The Congo and Other Poems, the influential Poetry magazine editor Harriet Monroe praised the "young Illinois troubadour" who had given an eccentric reading of the title poem at her magazine's banquet in honor of William Butler Yeats that year.1 A review in the New Republic described Lindsay's dynamic performance: "his body tense and swaying, his hands keeping time like an orchestral leader to his own rhythms, his tone changing color in response to the noise and savage imagery of the lines."2 At the start of his career, Lindsay had wandered as a vagabond poet, trading his verses for something to eat (naming, in fact, one of his early pamphlets Rhymes to Be Traded for Food and Bread). With "The Congo"—and its "savage imagery"—he became a household name. The long poem, accompanied by stage directions and placed first in a section of the book subtitled "Poems intended to be read aloud, or chanted," excited many readers and listeners at the time as authentically "primitive," but will undoubtedly strike a modern reader as a versified display of racial caricature and Afrophobia, complete with "glowering witch-men" and "tattooed cannibals." In a note appended to the poem when it appeared in a later edition, Lindsay writes that it "was suggested by an allusion in a sermon by my pastor, F. W. Burnham, to the heroic life and death of Ray Eldred. Eldred was a missionary of the Disciples of Christ who perished while swimming a treacherous branch of the Congo."3

div1.note: 1 Harriet Monroe, Introduction to "The Congo" and Other Poems, 1914.
2 R.S.B., "Sincerity in the Making," The New Republic, 5 Dec. 1914, 26-27.
